Award.AwardTitle: Metabolic Engineering 11 Conference, June 26-30, 2016; Kobe, Japan

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1634294
Gill, Ryan T.

This proposal seeks support for the 11th International Conference on Metabolic Engineering (ME11) to be held at the Awaji Yumebutai International Conference Center in Kobe, Japan. The Metabolic Engineering Conference is a leading conference for sharing the state-of-the-art developments and achievements made in the field of metabolic engineering over the last two years. The theme of this year's conference is Design, Synthesis and System Integration for Metabolic Engineering. The Conference is one of the first among several conference series related to biotechnology that started 20 years ago as an Engineering Foundation conference with focus on recombinant DNA technology. It has been the first conference with explicit focus on the application of recombinant DNA technology to the engineering of microorganisms for industrial processes. This metabolic engineering relies now on the tools commonly referred to as synthetic biology and systems biology. This conference has been instrumental in addressing issues contemporary to technological advancements, engineering research and to education.

The scope of this international conference is to bring together influential established researchers, young investigators, industrial researchers and practitioners, and graduate students to assess the contributions and future opportunities of metabolic engineering with focus on biological design and synthesis. The support will enable attendance by graduate students, postdocs, academic scientists and engineers and industrial researchers that will benefit from interactions with the international community of biotechnology researchers.

Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the Conference, the award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metabolic Engineering 11 (ME11) was held from June 26-30, 2016 at the Awaji Yumebutai International Conference Center and the Westin Awaji Island in Kobe, Japan. It was organized jointly by the International Metabolic Engineering Society, the Society for Biological Engineering, Kobe University, and Osaka University. The conference was chaired by: Akihiko Kondo, Kobe University and Hiroshi Shimizu, Osaka University. 

The Co-Chairs, Steering Committee, and Scientific Advisory Board ensured a quality technical program and the overall success of the conference.

Co-Chairs

  • Mark Burk, Genomatica, USA
  • George Chen, Tsinghua University, China
  • Ryan Gill, University of Colorado, USA
  • Wataru Mizunashi, Mitsubishi Chemical Group, Japan
  • Christoph Wittman, Saarland University, Germany

Steering Committee

  • Jens Nielsen, Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden
  • Vassily Hatzimanikatis, EPFL, Switzerland
  • Sang Yup Lee, KAIST, South Korea
  • Jim Liao, UCLA, USA
  • Greg Stephanopoulos, MIT, USA
  • June Wispelwey, AIChE, USA

Scientific Advisory Board

  • Ryan Gill, University of Colorado, USA
  • Vassily Hatzimanikatis, EPFL, Switzerland
  • Joseph Heijnen, TU Delft, Netherlands
  • Sang Yup Lee, KAIST, South Korea
  • Jim Liao, UCLA, USA
  • Jens Nielsen, Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden
  • Matthias Reuss, University of Stuttgart, Germany
  • Anthony Sinskey, MIT, USA
  • Philippe Soucaille, University of Toulouse, France
  • Greg Stephanopoulos, MIT, USA

ME11 followed the successes of the previous ten conferences, with the prior event (ME-X) held in 2014 in Vancouver, Canada. ME11 brought together 500 attendees, with wide international representation, who shared state-of-the-art developments and achievements made in the field of metabolic engineering. These attendees are experts that are both top class academic researchers as well as highly regarded industrial scientists and engineers. There were a significant number of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and young professionals.

The technical program included 2 keynote presentations, 40 invited presentations, and 30 oral presentations. In addition there were over 250 poster presentations distributed over 3 poster sessions. Technical sessions integrated talks discussing the recent achievements made in the fields of systems biology, synthetic biology, biochemical engineering, synthetic enzyme, evolutionary engineering, integrated omics, tools and methods, and emerging techniques, healthcare, biofuels, chemicals and materials, biologics, microbial and mammalian systems, and other disciplines and applications.

Conference Topics

  • Metabolic Engineering for Fuels and Chemicals
  • Molecular Parts and Metabolic Engineering
  • Synthetic Biology and Metabolic Engineering
  • Computational Tools and Methods for Metabolic Engineering
  • Metabolic Engineering for Chemicals and Materials
  • Metabolic Engineering of Industrial Microorganisms
  • Omics Science and Metabolic Engineering
  • Metabolic Engineering for Cell Culture and Medical Applications
  • Industrial Applications of Metabolic Engineering
  • Metabolic Engineering: Methods and Application

In addition to the technical program there was an Awards Ceremony where leaders of Metabolic Engineering were recognized.

  • The 2016 International Metabolic Engineering Award was presented to Bernhard Palsson, University of California, San Diego for being an outstanding career contributor to the field.
  • The 2016 Jay Bailey Young Investigator Award in Metabolic Engineering was presented to Irina Borodina, Technical University of Denmark to recognize her as a rising star in the field.
  • 10 poster presentations were selected to receive awards, with the awards limited to students and young professionals.

Complete information about the conference and access to the conference proceedings can be found on the conference website at http://www.aiche.org/sbe/conferences/metabolic-engineering-conference/2016.
